    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="text"><table data-table-type="yaml-metadata">

</table>

<h1><a id="user-content-getting-started" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#getting-started"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Getting Started</h1>
<p>In this book we will be using the
<a href="https://cran.r-project.org/" rel="nofollow">R programming language</a> for all our
analysis. You will learn R and statistics simultaneously. However, we
assume you have some basic programming skills and knowledge of R
syntax. If you don't, your first homework, listed below, is to
complete a tutorial. Here we give step-by-step instructions on how to
get set up to follow along.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-installing-r" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#installing-r"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Installing R</h2>
<p>The first step is to install R. You can download and install R from
the <a href="https://cran.r-project.org/" rel="nofollow">Comprehensive R Archive Network</a>
(CRAN). It is relatively straightforward, but if you need further help
you can try the following resources:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/genomicsclass/windows#installing-r">Installing R on Windows</a></li>
<li><a href="http://youtu.be/Icawuhf0Yqo" rel="nofollow">Installing R on Mac</a></li>
<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/bin/linux/ubuntu/README" rel="nofollow">Installing R on Ubuntu</a></li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="user-content-installing-rstudio" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#installing-rstudio"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Installing RStudio</h2>
<p>The next step is to install RStudio, a program for viewing and running
R scripts. Technically you can run all the code shown here without
installing RStudio, but we highly recommend this integrated
development environment (IDE). Instructions are
<a href="http://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/" rel="nofollow">here</a> and for
Windows we have special
<a href="https://github.com/genomicsclass/windows">instructions</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-learn-r-basics" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#learn-r-basics"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Learn R Basics</h2>
<p>The first homework assignment is to complete an R tutorial to
familiarize yourself with the basics of programming and R syntax.
To follow this book you should be familiar with the difference between lists (including data frames) and numeric vectors, for-loops, how to create functions, and how to use the <code>sapply</code> and <code>replicate</code> functions.</p>
<p>If you are already familiar with R, you can skip to the next section. Otherwise, you should go through the <a href="http://swirlstats.com/" rel="nofollow">swirl</a> tutorial, which teaches you R programming and data science interactively, at your own pace and in the R console. Once you have R installed, you can install <code>swirl</code> and run it the following way:</p>
<pre lang="{r,"><code>install.packages("swirl")
library(swirl)
swirl()
</code></pre>
<p>Alternatively you can take the <a href="http://tryr.codeschool.com/" rel="nofollow">try R</a> interactive class from Code School.</p>
<p>There are also many open and free resources and reference
guides for R. Two examples are:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.statmethods.net/" rel="nofollow">Quick-R</a>: a quick online reference for data input, basic statistics and plots</li>
<li>R reference card (PDF)[<a href="https://cran.r-project.org/doc/contrib/Short-refcard.pdf" rel="nofollow">https://cran.r-project.org/doc/contrib/Short-refcard.pdf</a>] by Tom Short</li>
</ul>
<p>Two key things you need to know about R is that you can get help for a function using <code>help</code> or <code>?</code>, like this:</p>
<pre lang="{r,eval=FALSE}"><code>?install.packages
help("install.packages")
</code></pre>
<p>and the hash character represents comments, so text following these
characters is not interpreted:</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>##This is just a comment
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-installing-packages" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#installing-packages"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Installing Packages</h2>
<p>The first R command we will run is <code>install.packages</code>. If you took the
<code>swirl</code> tutorial you should have already done this. R only includes a basic set of
functions. It can do much more than this, but not everybody needs
everything so we instead make some functions available via
packages. Many of these functions are stored in CRAN. Note that these
packages are vetted: they are checked for common errors and they must have
a dedicated maintainer. You can easily install packages from within R if you know
the name of the packages. As an example, we are going to install the
package <code>rafalib</code> which we use in our first data
analysis examples:</p>
<pre lang="{r,eval=FALSE}"><code>install.packages("rafalib")
</code></pre>
<p>We can then load the package into our R sessions using the <code>library</code> function:</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>library(rafalib)
</code></pre>
<p>From now on you will see that we sometimes load packages without
installing them. This is because once you install the package, it
remains in place and only needs to be loaded with <code>library</code>. If you
try to load a package and get an error, it probably means you need to
install it first.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-importing-data-into-r" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#importing-data-into-r"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Importing Data into R</h2>
<p>The first step when preparing to analyze data is to read in the data into R. There are several ways to do this and we will discuss three of them. But you only need to learn one to follow along.</p>
<p>In the life sciences, small datasets such as the one used as an
example in the next sections are typically stored as Excel files. Although there
are R packages designed to read Excel (xls) format, you generally want
to avoid this and save files as comma delimited (Comma-Separated
Value/CSV) or tab delimited (Tab-Separated Value/TSV/TXT) files.
These plain-text formats are often easier for sharing data with
collaborators, as commercial software is not required for viewing or
working with the data.
We will start with a simple example dataset containing
<a href="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/genomicsclass/dagdata/master/inst/extdata/femaleMiceWeights.csv" rel="nofollow">female mouse weights</a>.</p>
<p>The first step is to find the file containing your data and know its <em>path</em>.</p>
<h4><a id="user-content-paths-and-the-working-directory" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#paths-and-the-working-directory"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Paths and the Working Directory</h4>
<p>When you are working in R it is useful to know your <em>working directory</em>. This is the directory or folder in which R will save or look for files by default. You can see your working directory by typing:</p>
<pre lang="{r,"><code>getwd()
</code></pre>
<p>You can also change your working directory using the function <code>setwd</code>. Or you can change it through RStudio by clicking on "Session".</p>
<p>The functions that read and write files (there are several in R) assume you mean to look for files or write files in the working directory. Our recommended approach for beginners will have you reading and writing to the working directory. However, you can also type the <a href="http://www.computerhope.com/jargon/a/absopath.htm" rel="nofollow">full path</a>, which will work independently of the working directory.</p>
<h4><a id="user-content-projects-in-rstudio" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#projects-in-rstudio"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Projects in RStudio</h4>
<p>We find that the simplest way to organize yourself is to start a Project in RStudio (Click on "File" and "New Project"). When creating the project, you will select a folder to be associated with it. You can then download all your data into this folder. Your working directory will be this folder.</p>
<h4><a id="user-content-option-1-read-file-over-the-internet" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#option-1-read-file-over-the-internet"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Option 1: Read file over the Internet</h4>
<p>You can navigate to the <code>femaleMiceWeights.csv</code> file by visiting the
data directory of dagdata on
<a href="https://github.com/genomicsclass/dagdata/tree/master/inst/extdata">GitHub</a>. If you navigate to the file, you need to click on <em>Raw</em> on the
upper right hand corner of the page.</p>
<p><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/genomicsclass/labs/blob/master/intro/images/handmade/screenshot1.png"><img src="/genomicsclass/labs/raw/master/intro/images/handmade/screenshot1.png" alt="GitHub page screenshot." style="max-width:100%;"></a></p>
<p>Now you can copy and paste the URL and use this as the argument to <code>read.csv</code>.
Here we break the URL into a base directory and a filename and then combine
with <code>paste0</code> because the URL would otherwise be too long for the page.
We use <code>paste0</code> because we want to put the strings together as is, if you were
specifying a file on your machine you should use the smarter function, <code>file.path</code>,
which knows the difference between Windows and Mac file path connectors.
You can specify the URL using a single string to avoid this extra step.</p>
<pre lang="{r,message=FALSE}"><code>dir &lt;- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/genomicsclass/dagdata/master/inst/extdata/"
url &lt;- paste0(dir, "femaleMiceWeights.csv")
dat &lt;- read.csv(url)
</code></pre>
<h4><a id="user-content-option-2-download-file-with-your-browser-to-your-working-directory" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#option-2-download-file-with-your-browser-to-your-working-directory"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Option 2: Download file with your browser to your working directory</h4>
<p>There are reasons for wanting to keep a local copy of the file. For example, you may want to run the analysis while not connected to the Internet or you may want to ensure reproducibility regardless of the file being available on the original site. To download the file, as in option 1, you can navigate to the <code>femaleMiceWeights.csv</code>. In this option we use your browser's "Save
As" function to ensure that the downloaded file is in a CSV
format. Some browsers add an extra suffix to your filename by
default. You do not want this. You want your file to be named
<code>femaleMiceWeights.csv</code>. Once you have this file in your working directory, then you can simply read it in like this:</p>
<pre lang="{r,eval=FALSE}"><code>dat &lt;- read.csv("femaleMiceWeights.csv")
</code></pre>
<p>If you did not receive any message, then you probably read in the file successfully.</p>
<h4><a id="user-content-option-3-download-the-file-from-within-r" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#option-3-download-the-file-from-within-r"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Option 3: Download the file from within R</h4>
<p>We store many of the datasets used here on <a href="https://github.com/genomicsclass/">GitHub</a>. You can save these files directly from the Internet to your computer using R. In this example, we are using the <code>download.file</code> function in the <code>downloader</code> package to download the file to a specific location and then read it in. We can assign it a random name and a random directory using the function <code>tempfile</code>, but you can also save it in directory with the name of your choosing.</p>
<pre lang="{r,message=FALSE}"><code>library(downloader) ##use install.packages to install
dir &lt;- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/genomicsclass/dagdata/master/inst/extdata/"
filename &lt;- "femaleMiceWeights.csv" 
url &lt;- paste0(dir, filename)
if (!file.exists(filename)) download(url, destfile=filename)
</code></pre>
<p>We can then proceed as in option 2:</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>dat &lt;- read.csv(filename)
</code></pre>
<h4><a id="user-content-option-4-download-the-data-package-advanced" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#option-4-download-the-data-package-advanced"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Option 4: Download the data package (Advanced)</h4>
<p>Many of the datasets we include in this book are available in custom-built packages from GitHub. The reason we use GitHub, rather than CRAN, is that on GitHub we do not have to vet packages, which gives us much more flexibility.</p>
<p>To install packages from GitHub you will need to install the <code>devtools</code> package:</p>
<pre lang="{r,eval=FALSE}"><code>install.packages("devtools")
</code></pre>
<p>Note to Windows users: to use devtools you will have to also install <code>Rtools</code>. In general you will need to install packages as administrator. One way to do this is to start R as administrator. If you do not have permission to do this, then it is a bit <a href="http://www.magesblog.com/2012/04/installing-r-packages-without-admin.html" rel="nofollow">more complicated</a>.</p>
<p>Now you are ready to install a package from GitHub. For this we use a different function:</p>
<pre lang="{r,message=FALSE,eval=FALSE}"><code>library(devtools)
install_github("genomicsclass/dagdata")
</code></pre>
<p>The file we are working with is actually included in this package. Once you install the package, the file is on your computer. However, finding it requires advanced knowledge. Here are the lines of code:</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>dir &lt;- system.file(package="dagdata") #extracts the location of package
list.files(dir)
list.files(file.path(dir,"extdata")) #external data is in this directory
</code></pre>
<p>And now we are ready to read in the file:</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>filename &lt;- file.path(dir,"extdata/femaleMiceWeights.csv")
dat &lt;- read.csv(filename)
</code></pre>
</article>

  <template id="site-details-dialog">
  <details class="details-reset details-overlay details-overlay-dark lh-default text-gray-dark" open>
    <summary aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-label="Close dialog"></summary>

      <button class="Box-btn-octicon m-0 btn-octicon position-absolute right-0 top-0" type="button" aria-label="Close dialog" data-close-dialog>
        <svg class="octicon octicon-x" viewBox="0 0 12 16" version="1.1" width="12" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.48 8l3.75 3.75-1.48 1.48L6 9.48l-3.75 3.75-1.48-1.48L4.52 8 .77 4.25l1.48-1.48L6 6.52l3.75-3.75 1.48 1.48L7.48 8z"/></svg>
      </button>
      <div class="octocat-spinner my-6 js-details-dialog-spinner"></div>
    </details-dialog>
  </details>
</template>

  <div class="Popover js-hovercard-content position-absolute" style="display: none; outline: none;" tabindex="0">
  <div class="Popover-message Popover-message--bottom-left Popover-message--large Box box-shadow-large" style="width:360px;">
  </div>
</div>

<div id="hovercard-aria-description" class="sr-only">
  Press h to open a hovercard with more details.
</div>
